replies.text: Imagine the gains youd make if you simply didnt invest in companies with scandals or sour sentiment.

BABA is up 25 over the past year while VOO is up 38 so thats not the success story youre making it out to be. Success in the market isnt just making a profit. If youre not beating the SP then youre losing. Bear in mind that while youre sitting on cash waiting for the next piece of bad news, that money isnt appreciating like it would with a set it and forget it approach. Also every time one of your picks starts to plateau and you decide to sell you have to give the tax man his cut which means you have less to reinvest. If you have to sell before youve owned the stock for a year then youll have to pay capital gains which will cut into your profit even more. All these things plus the fact that there isnt a guarantee that a stock will bounce back from bad news means that this is probably not the slam dunk you think it is. You may get lucky a few times but its probably not a sustainable investing strategy.

From a strictly mechanical standpoint, both buybacks and dividends return value to shareholders. They just do it in different ways. The main things that make buybacks more efficient than dividends is 1 they are more tax efficient for shareholders, and 2 they are more flexible for companies. As far as taxes, shareholders are taxed when they receive a dividend unless you automatically reinvest it in the stock. There are no taxes paid during a buyback. And from a flexibility standpoint, a company can start, pause, and resume a buyback pretty much at will. Whereas with dividends, once you start paying one, youre basically locked into it forever. Investors HATE it when a company cuts or stops its dividend.

Because any good company to work for these days offers RSUs, so if you dont buyback stock the price will go down because you issue more and more shares. Used to be only executives who got shares through options, but when an individual contributor can get them its a game changer. Take a look at SNOW as an example

Dividends use the companys cash to take equity out of the business and give to shareholders as cash. Buybacks use the companys cash to increase the shareholders equity in the business by buying down the share count. They are two different things and both can be valid uses of the companys cash. Both can also be bad uses of the company cash and shareholders can make their opinions known on this by selling the stock.

Because dividends force your hand to declare them in future quarters in increasing amounts, buybacks dont. Also, better tax treatment for the shareholder buy receiving cash from a buyback return of capital vs dividend return on capital

replies.text: I was up 200 on shares of F, so I sold them a few days ago and put it all into RIVN. Here are my thoughts They are a ways away from being profitable. Being profitable in automotive means being able to churn out volume. But theyre getting g there with Amazon, USPS and FedEx fleet contracts. Their trucks are just so nice to drive. They feel so premium in every way, and pretty much every Rivian owner Ive encountered loves their truck! They push out new features all the time, and those features actually seem to work. The R2 is coming out next year and the R3R3X the year after. This is where theyll gain a lot of market share, because they are affordable. People think EVs are going away, but how many KIAs Model 3s, and Model Ys do you see on a daily basis? Millions! And once people start installing home chargers, their gasmaintenance costs will fall dramatically. Of the EV stocks, I think RIVN has the best story. Lucid might have the best car, but Rivian especially with VW investment has a lot of upside, IMO

Snowflake got huge from companies that were expanding their data analytics that was true specially during covid as enterprises were accelerating their digital spend. But that head wind is gone and now they face heavy competition from data bricks and companies are also cutting back on this spent to focus more on Ai. It doesnt help that SNOW heavily relies on stock based compensation and loosing a ton of due to that. The minute they cut back on stock based compensation all top talent will flee. Which will crush their growth rate even more. They are stuck in dilemma of slowing growth and huge losses..

RIVN is the other pure EV company besides Tesla. Theres an argument RIVN will eventually be viable. They have products people like and a CEO who isnt crazy. The downside is their very small scale and lack of profitability. They didnt expand their production that much this year and steep ongoing losses forced them to mothball their planned new factory in some emergency cost cutting. Those losses also did cast some doubt on their runway and viability to continue. BUT theres counterpoint good news for all of that. One, theyve now been backstopped by a 5 billion ? commitment from VW, so the worries of cash starvation, dilution and bankruptcy are off the table for several years, assuming VW honors the agreement. The modest production numbers do at least reflect accurate and realistic forecasting, and the credibility of the CEO. Many even bet theyd never get to production at all, then doubted how many units. Hes delivered on his promises all along the way, which no other EV company seems to do. Rivian vehicles are expensive, and the headline numbers suggest that they need high margins but that means keeping prices high. The upside is their low production numbers mean at their scale they only need to attract affluent buyers anyway. But if they ever scale up, theyll have to solve the margin puzzle and so far it doesnt seem like they can do both. Maybe with VW being more actively invovled?

I think SNOW had a head start in the data warehouse data lake space with a great execlevel marketing campaign that hit precovid and at the time, a clear and differentiated product. Sales cycles were really fast, and companies were all onboard with this idea of one unified analytics platform where they could push all their data and easily enable new usecases. In reality, while Snowflake works, it doesnt have anything close to the extended capabilities of the big3 mature cloud platforms AWS, GCP Azure and the difficulty remains in orchestrating useful data usecases. Simultaneously, the hyperscalers have continued to develop and push their own competing platforms why would i leave my full GCP stack to do random oneoff work on Snowflake that I could do on BigQuery? Or Redshift, or SynapseFabric? And then at least I have a mature AI platform next to my data Snowpark is an absolute joke. Not to mention that Databricks has done a much better job of winning over developers than Snowflake has, and Databricks integrates better with existing cloud providers. I dont think SNOW is dead, and I think the rising tide in AI will life all data boats, but I personally look at the low PE hyperscalers as being a more interesting option in the next few years.

I dont think anyone thinks electric vehicles are going anywhere. The issue is consumers dont want to pay the prices manufacturers are charging for the models they have available. Beyond that, the home charging issue isnt going to be resolved by people simply installing chargers at home. The issue exists because many people, especially in cities where EVs are most common and future buyers are most likely to live, rent. Electric vehicles are the future but there are a lot of barriers standing in their way for many consumers that just dont make them worth it for them, currently.

once people start installing home chargers, their gasmaintenance costs will fall dramatically This concerns me about the EV space in general. More people in the country are renting than ever before, and landlords arent generally going to put in chargers without some kind of mandate. Beyond that, the cost to install a home charger is variable, it sometimes depends on the building and can get wildly costly if a significant upgrade to the ejection system is needed to support that. I wont even get into public chargers and how common they arent, because that part is largely irrelevant and could be rectified faster than the other issues. General example from my own life, I considered going EV on my last upgrade. My reality was that I was going to have to park at my local police station for over an hour once per week, and it would be a 20 minute walk back and forth to my apartment if I didnt want to sit in the parking lot that whole time. Convincing my landlord to install a charger at our apartment building has logistical problems because there is nowhere obvious to put one let alone two or three, even if convincing them to do it is a slam dunk it isnt. So here I am with a gas car, not by choice, and I dont see a path to a convienienient charger unless I move.

The need for data and processing is not going anywhere , so Im not worried about it. Many people think companies pick one product or the other but almost any company of reasonable size has mutiple products. So Im not worried about lack of demand or a crowded space because I believe neither of those are true. But the stock compensation I do believe is a real issue
why would i leave my full GCP stack to do random oneoff work on Snowflake that I could do on BigQuery? Or Redshift, or SynapseFabric? Because all of those options suck comparatively.

Databricks is more expensive than Snowflake. Databricks also requires more manpowerlabor to get it up and running due to its running on Spark whereas Snowflake is more towards the it just works philosophy.

Another problem with the home charging is the power grid. I lived in St Louis County for over 61 years. When I left, county officials were saying if more than two residences in each subdivision required home charging, they didnt have the power to supply it. We have a long way to go to make electric cars for the masses. It is going to take some time.
I know its a drop in the bucket, but an increasing amount of new construction dwellings are coming with EV hookups installed already.

Redshift is more performant and cost effective than Snowflake now, its nuts. Everything flipped in the last few years, while Snowflake did almost nothing.
The do suck right now but for how long.

This. The right cost comparison seems to be data scientists Snowflake vs data scientists Databricks engineers to manage it. Data scientists are tasked with using data to improve the business, the rest is overhead to support their work. If you ask a team of engineers who know how to run the open source stack themselves, theyll prefer Databricks because it makes that easier while Snowflake makes it impossible and for many use cases unnecessary.

Going to redirect to ChatGPT because it will answer the question in far more detail than I ever could The behavior youre describing aligns with what some people refer to as swing trading, which involves holding a stock for a short period days to weeks to capitalize on expected price movements. Its different from day trading, where traders buy and sell stocks within the same day, often executing multiple trades in a single day. Many retail investors might buy and hold stocks for short or long periods based on their strategy, market outlook, or financial goals. When you see people talking about buying, holding, or selling specific stocks, they could be Day Traders Buying and selling stocks within the same trading day to profit from small price fluctuations. Swing Traders Holding stocks for a few days to weeks, aiming to profit from shortterm market movements. LongTerm Investors Buying and holding stocks for months or years, focusing on the companys growth or dividends rather than shortterm price changes. Your plan to buy a stock and sell it after a couple of weeks fits more with swing trading. Many people engage in this type of trading to get a taste of the market or to try and make shortterm profits. If you proceed, keep in mind the following Transaction Costs Ensure the potential profit is more than the trading fees, if applicable. Tax Implications In a taxable brokerage account, selling a stock within a year could subject you to shortterm capital gains tax, which is typically higher than longterm capital gains tax. Market Risk Stock prices can be unpredictable in the short term, and your expected profit might not materialize. If this approach appeals to you, youre not alonemany people test the waters of the stock market this way.

Rajesh, I dont think you understand convertible bond with 0% interest. Here is the way it works: a bond buyer basically lends 2 billion dollars to snowflake. Now they get assigned shares at $157. Thats a 40% premium with a 3-5 year horizon. Lets say in 2027 snowflake is $150. The buyer will be returned the $1 billion they gave as loan with zero interest. On the other hand, if the share price is $200. Bond buyer is profitable as he will convert to shares and sell it for a $43 profit per share. Also, its 2 billion with 1 billion due in 2027 and 1 billion due in 2029. Its capped to $397 per share. Meaning the buyer cannot opt for shares on an earlier date unless the stock prices stays above $397. Hope you get this.
